Dinkes: 35 Persen Orang Jakarta Obesitas
05 Nov 2019, 16:50 by , https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


Dinkes DKI Jakarta menyebut bahwa dari 1,3 juta responden warga Jakarta, sebagian besarnya punya perilaku hidup tak sehat dan risiko punya penyakit tak menular.(Istockphoto/MediaProduction)

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia -- Penyakit tidak menular (PTM) makin marak di Indonesia juga di DKI Jakarta. DinasÂ Kesehatan (Dinkes) DKI Jakarta melihat potret data masukan dan menyimpulkan bahwa musti ada yang berubah yakni perilaku masyarakat.Himpunan data Dinkes DKI Jakarta pada 2019 dari 1,3 juta responden warga Jakarta (data BPS DKI 2018, ada 10,4 juta warga Jakarta) ada setidaknya 12 persen orang memiliki kebiasaan merokok, 30 persen orang (dari berbagai usia) kurang konsumsi buah dan sayur, 36 persen kurang aktivitas fisik. Selain itu, berdasarkan data ditemukan 35 persen orang mengalami obesitas, dan obesitas sentral sebanyak 49 persen.Obesitas sentral merupakan kondisi kelebihan berat badan dilihat dari lingkar pinggang. Pria dikatakan mengalami obesitas sentral jika memiliki lingkar pinggang lebih dari 90 centimeter sedangkan wanita lebih dari 80 centimeter. Menurut Dwi Oktavia Handayani, Kepala Bidang pencegahan & Pengendalian Penyakit, Dinkes DKI Jakarta, obesitas merupakan faktor risiko terbesar dari PTM."Ini kondisi yang sangat serius, kita harus edukasi masyarakat untuk mengubah perilaku, paksa untuk bergerak lebih dan memilih makanan," kata Dwi di sela kampanye kolaborasi Nutrifood dan Alfamart serta Alfamidi di Alfamidi Super Bangka Raya, Mampang Prapatan, Jakarta Selatan, Selasa (5/11).Dinkes sendiri bergerak dengan kampanye CERDIK yakni, Cek kesehatan secara rutin, Enyahkan asap rokok, Rajin olahraga (minimal 150 menit per minggu), Diet seimbang (cukup serat, lemak, karbohidrat tidak berlebihan), Istirahat cukup dan Kelola stres. Dwi menambahkan pihaknya juga mendorong fasilitas kesehatan primer harus bisa skrining PTM pada warga usia produktif."Puskesmas bergerak aktif menemui warga biar bisa mengenali lebih dini termasuk gula darah," katanya.Pihak Dinkes pun bekerja sama dengan korporasi untuk bersama bergerak mengampanyekan pemeriksaan kesehatan. Paling minim, warga sadar dan tahu kondisi tubuhnya berkaitan dengan kadar gula darah, kolesterol dan tekanan darah. (els/chs)

Health Office: 35 Percent of Jakarta Obesity People
05 Nov 2019, 16:50 by, https://www.facebook.com/CNNIndonesia


DKI Jakarta Health Office said that of the 1.3 million respondents in Jakarta, most of them had unhealthy living behaviors and the risk of having non-communicable diseases. (Istockphoto / MediaProduction)

Jakarta, CNN Indonesia - Non-communicable diseases (PTM) are increasingly prevalent in Indonesia as well as in DKI Jakarta. The DKI Jakarta Health Office (Dinkes) looks at the portrait of input data and concludes that there must be a change in the behavior of the community. The data collection of the DKI Jakarta Health Office in 2019 from 1.3 million respondents in Jakarta (BPS DKI data 2018, there are 10.4 million Jakarta residents ) there are at least 12 percent of people have smoking habits, 30 percent of people (of various ages) consume less fruit and vegetables, 36 percent lack physical activity. In addition, based on data found 35 percent of people are obese, and as much as 49 percent of central obesity. Central obesity is a condition of being overweight seen from the waist circumference. Men are said to have central obesity if they have a waist circumference of more than 90 centimeters while women are more than 80 centimeters. According to Dwi Oktavia Handayani, Head of Disease Prevention & Control Division, DKI Jakarta Health Office, obesity is the biggest risk factor of PTM. "This is a very serious condition, we must educate the public to change behavior, force them to move more and choose food," Dwi said on the sidelines of the collaboration campaign of Nutrifood and Alfamart and Alfamidi at Alfamidi Super Bangka Raya, Mampang Prapatan, South Jakarta, Tuesday (11/5). The Health Office itself moves with the CERDIK campaign namely, Regular health checks, Get rid of cigarette smoke, Diligent sports (minimum 150 minutes per week), balanced diet (enough fiber, fat, not excessive carbohydrates), adequate rest and stress management. Dwi added that his party also encourages primary health facilities to be able to screen PTM in productive age residents. "Puskesmas actively moves to meet citizens so they can recognize early, including blood sugar," he said. The DHOs also cooperated with corporations to jointly campaign for health checks. At the very least, residents are aware and know that their body condition is related to blood sugar, cholesterol and blood pressure levels. (els / chs)
